Currently we ignore the exception in task closing. The reason seems we think the task is completed anyway.  If user task cannot be disposed properly, in fault tolerant case, with a dirty platform, there might be issues if we re-submit a task on the same evaluator.  
So I think if dispose throw exception after task call is returned, we might want to fail the evaluator.
@jwang98052 Does this mean this PR should not move forward? Or are you suggesting a follow-up JIRA/PR?

This PR documents current behavior. The behavior change required would be in core REEF (`TaskRuntime`), and if we decide to proceed with it, it should definitely be a separate work item, which would include updates to our affected tests (there might be more than just this one).
OK. I will go ahead and merge this once the tests complete successfully on my machine.

That's right. Ignore dispose exception after the task call is the current behavior. The tests in this PR is based on that behavior.  Of course now we start to call user task function dispose that increase a chance to get exception in dispose rather than only from system's dispose method. But I agree it should be in a separate Jira.
I have other two minor comments before the merge,
OK, I will not merge the change as is then.

@markusweimer To answer your questions:
1. There is no any change outside IMRU in this PR. Some classes are named as PipelinedBroadcastReduce, they were/are in IMRU namespace. 
2. IMRU.Example and IMRU are in separate dlls. UpdateResult was defined in IMRU and used in IMRU.Exmaple before the change. In the entire PR, I only enabled two properties in UpdateResult to be public. As UpdateResult has been exposed to public, and seems it was designed for the client to use it to hold update results in update function as a template. I don't see any potential issues for enabling its properties as public.  
3. For IMRU example, if you concern is to make the basic task function simple, I can keep it and add another update function with state management in fault tolerant example.
I have fixed everything you requested and then pushed the updated rebased branch from my dev machine to origin REEF-1554 and the changes do not show up here. What am I missing?

The changes are reflected in this PR. 
If you add new commit on top of the old one, Github will show it smartly, collapsing review comments which relate to code which is already fixed etc. But I think you've squashed new commit into the old one, so now this PR shows only one commit, Github doesn't know where the comments belong to and doesn't collapse them.
I'll take a look
My understanding is that all REEF commits should be rebased and squashed into one. What is the proper procedure to meet both REEF standards and get the code changed after the review to show up?

Correct, the committer does rebase and squash commits from one PR right before merging it into master. However, once code review was started and there are any comments left, it's more convenient to keep the history of commits, so that it's possible to look either at the change as a whole or at the changes done since reviewer last looked at it (if there are few of them), and to keep track of where comments belong. So it's best to just add commits on top of existing ones.

Okay now I understand. I will squash the first push for the code review, make a new commit for each change during the code review, then the final REEF committer will do a squash after the code is reviewed and accepted. Thanks.

I have moved state management related code to fault tolerant examples and tests. Leaving the original IMRU map/update function example as it was.

This change assumes that we are using C# 6 which was released with Visual Studio 2015, right? Earlier versions of C# did not support read-only auto properties. I'm fine with requiring VS2015 to build REEF at this point.

Does this impose requirements on the runtime of people using REEF? Do they need .NET 4.6?

@markusweimer I agree with your comments about making methods public in principle. However, in this particular case it seems that doing the change you're suggesting and testing it thoroughly will take significant amount of time and increase the complexity of this PR. I propose that we

1) file a separate JIRA to modify the example as you suggest and make these properties private again.
2) annotate these properties as `Unstable` with JIRA number, so that we clearly communicate our intention regarding them.
3) merge this PR soon to unblock further work on doing state preservation for the specific algorithm we need. This work would _not_ rely on these public properties.
4) work on the example modification JIRA without blocking algorithm work. This change will also have smaller scope and fewer conflicts with other changes going in.

What do you think?

Regarding injection, the configuration passed from args is the one needed to inject REEFLauncher and the merged configuration with LAUNCHER_STATIC_CONFIG is the config needed to inject REEFEnvironment, REEFVersion, REEFErrorHandler and Clock. So I would suggest 
1. the main program in REEFLauncher first create the configuration (from args + LAUNCHER_STATIC_CONFIG), then create an injector from it. 
2. If you need to have multiple REEFEnvironment, you can folk injector and inject the REEFEnvironment. 
3. REEFEnvironment constructor parameters can have Injector, REEFVersion and REEFErrorHandler. They will be automatically injected without using getInstance(). 
4. The same injector passed in REEFEnvironment can be used to getInstance of Clock inside REEFEnvironment constructor code. At that time, you already have REEFErrorHandler injected.

>  However, in this particular case it seems that doing the change you're suggesting and testing it thoroughly will take significant amount of time and increase the complexity of this PR. 

What's the extra work we are talking about? All we need to do is replace the changes to the examples with changes that use some other form of state, e.g. a single `double`, instead of the state formed by `UpdateResult`, right?
@markusweimer I think I've fixed all the issues that you mention, and created JIRAs and TODOs for the follow-up changes. Could you please take another look? Thanks!

@markusweimer @dkm2110 I have changed UpdateTaskState to store individual state instead of UpdateResult, hence leaving internal properties in UpdateResult as it was. Please have another look.

```
Error message:

Assert.Equal() Failure
Expected: 5
Actual:   4

Error stack trace:
   at Org.Apache.REEF.Tests.Functional.IMRU.TestFailedUpdateEvaluatorInWaitingForEvaluatorState.TestFailedUpdateEvaluatorAtContextOnLocalRuntime() in C:\projects\reef\lang\cs\Org.Apache.REEF.Tests\Functional\IMRU\TestFailedUpdateEvaluatorInWaitingForEvaluatorState.cs:line 59
```

We already have a lot of unstable tests which will be a trouble once we approach next release. So I think we should investigate instability of new ones before merging them in the code base.
